content:
Hi @T-compiler/meeting; the triage meeting will take place in about 2h
WG-prioritization has done pre-triage in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts and prepared the meeting agenda

Scheduled checkins from:

  • @WG-async-foundations by @nikomatsakis @tmandry
  • @WG-traits by @nikomatsakis @Jack Huey
Hey everyone; my Internet is having big time problem. @wesleywiser are you available to run the mtg today?
@Wesley Wiser ^
Sure!
Welcome @T-compiler/meeting! Please leave a :wave: to show you're here.

Announcements

  • Tomorrow at 2021-08-27T10:00:00-04:00 Compiler Team Planning meeting (link)
• Tomorrow from 2021-08-27T10:00:00-04:00 until 2021-08-27T14:00:00-04:00 Polonius Hackathon on #t-compiler/wg-polonius, google meet link

• T-compiler agenda now has a new section: the 5 most recently updated PRs waiting for review (thanks @Santiago Pastorino for contributing the patch and @inquisitivecrystal for assigning the team label to most of them. Zulip discussion.
I can't react to my own message but yeah, thanks everyone who pitched in to make the PRs waiting for review list happen! :clap:
just in case, the heuristic is naive, the one that we've discussed
based on the most recent comment on the PR, we may want to make it better in the future
Seems fine to start with and we can always tweak it later!
WG checkins
@tmandry and @nikomatsakis is there anything to report from WG-async-foundations?
Seems like there's been a lot of activity in the Zulip stream lately :smile:

• @WG-traits by @nikomatsakis @Jack Huey (previous checkin)
    • #85499 was merged, which fixes the common OutputTypeParameterMismatch ICE (ends up closing over a dozen issues)
    • Continuing work on GATs
      • blog post announcing push for GATs stabilization
      • retconned lang initiatve repo - check out open design discussions, feedback welcome!
      • Multiple PRs opened/merged fixing bugs and diagnostics, will continue moving forward
    • Continuing work on type alias impl trait
      • Many tests added
      • Refactorings being done to change TAIT to act like an unbound ty var, simplifying the implementation and make it "trivial" to support more use cases than was originally planned for initial stabilization
    • Continuing work on trait upcasting
      • retconned lang initiative repo - check out open design discussions, feedback welcome!
      • A few PRs have been merged implement actual trait selection, type checking, and coercion
      • PR open for unsafety checking
It's really great seeing GATs move closer to stabilization! :tada:

Santiago Pastorino said:

based on the most recent comment on the PR, we may want to make it better in the future

I definitely think we should. These don't really reflect well just how old some of the non-reviewed PRs are (May)
MCPs/FCPs
GATs are exciting, yes. But did you see #85499!? I'm ecstatic!

Jack Huey said:

Santiago Pastorino said:

based on the most recent comment on the PR, we may want to make it better in the future

I definitely think we should. These don't really reflect well just how old some of the non-reviewed PRs are (May)

exactly :)

• New MCPs (take a look, see if you like them!)
    • No new proposals this time.

• Old MCPs (not seconded, take a look)
    • "Add different entry points for x.py" compiler-team#396 (last comment: GH 7m ago, Zulip 17d ago)
    • "rustdoc is using rustc_ast_pretty, would it be possible to make it somewhat "stable"?" compiler-team#403 (last comment: GH 6m ago, Zulip 2m ago)
    • "Don't steal the resolver when lowering HIR; instead store an immutable resolver in TyCtxt" compiler-team#437 (last comment: GH 2m ago, Zulip 2m ago)
    • "CI should exercise (subset of) tests under --stage 1" compiler-team#439 (last comment: GH 2m days ago, Zulip None)
    • "Accept pc in place of unknown and unknown in place of pc for x86_64 and i?86 targets" compiler-team#441 (last comment: GH about 2m ago, Zulip 2m ago)
    • "Non exhaustive reachable patterns lint" compiler-team#445 (last comment: GH about 40 days ago, Zulip 20d ago)
    • "Add TyKind::Const and remove GenericArgKind::Const" compiler-team#453 (last comment: GH about 6d ago, Zulip 10d ago)
    • "prefer-dynamic=subset" compiler-team#455 (last comment: GH about 6d ago, Zulip 8d ago)
  • Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • "Write text output files to stdout if options like -o - or --emit asm=- are provided" compiler-team#431
  • Things in FCP (make sure you're good with it)
    • "Make resolve_instance fallible" compiler-team#449
    • "Reproducible command line + determinism" compiler-team#450
    • "Make AST->HIR lowering incremental" compiler-team#452
    • "Transfer rustc-demangle to the @rust-lang GitHub org." compiler-team#456
    • "Extend -Cdebuginfo with new options and named aliases" rust#83947
  • Accepted MCPs
    • No new accepted proposals this time.
  • Finalized FCPs (disposition merge)
    • No new finished FCP (disposition merge) this time.
I'll call out @eddyb's proposal to transfer rustc-demangle to the rust-lang GH org since I seconded it pretty quickly but I think it isn't controversial. (compiler-team#456)
looks like an MCP that got seconded doesn't show up in "new MCPs"
heh yeah that one
(it's under "Things in FCP")
Ok, I think that's it for announcements...

Backport nominations

T-compiler stable / T-compiler beta
Question: There are a lot of MCPs that are pretty old. Is there a process to close these for inactivity?
I don't think we have a formal process there but it would be good to do some triage there.
(internet might be back now)
We have at least once dedicated a steering meeting to going through the list
(I think)
I recall that as well.

• "Always preserve sub-obligations in the projection cache" rust#85868
    • @nikomatsakis will try to review
    • @Jack Huey approved but mentions a substancial perf loss, thus the need to add some tests
to try to identify things that should obviously be closed, versus things that seem like they should be seconded and just needed some love
Looks like the review has happened, thanks @Jack Huey!
But we still need to land on nightly before we think about backporting IMO.
I'm going to skip this one and hopefully we will have landed it by the next triage meeting.

• "Split critical edge targeting the start block" rust#88124
    • Opened by @TM
    • Assigned to @oli
    • Nominated by @Wesley Wiser
    • Fixes #88043 a P-critical due to exposing an LLVM bug
I'm personally in favor of backporting to beta.
it's also stable nominated
I’m fine with backporting this. Were there multiple fixes landed for #88043 ?
because I’m trying to understand how there was already a regression test
oh, the revert PR probably added the regression test
(yes, that explains that)
#83417 exposed an existing issue tracked in #88043. #83417 was reverted in #88056 but the actual cause was resolved by #88124.
Ok, accepted.

• "Split critical edge targeting the start block" rust#88124
    • see above
How about stable?
beta accepted.
(wow I think my internet is still pretty busted)
It's not clear when the original issue was injected into stable so I'm happy to let this ride the train on beta. (decline to backport to stable :shrug: )
We are very late in the cycle.
Stable release is 2021-09-09. Good point @mw
Is this a risky fix? It seems rather small
I don't think it's risky.
Consensus seems to be to backport to stable so I'm ok with that.
Approved for stable backport.

T-rustdoc stable / T-rustdoc beta

  • No beta nominations for T-rustdoc this time.
  • No stable nominations for T-rustdoc this time.
The only misgiving I have is that it might require some finesse
You mean if the diff doesn't apply cleanly?
yeah, namely that situation with the regression test
but one should presumably be able to adapt
it just means its yet more time someone has to spend on it
Its a minor point
but I don't object to backport to stable
PRs S-waiting-on-team
T-compiler

• "move obligation dedup from impl_or_trait_obligations to project caching" rust#84944 (last comment: about 16 days ago)
    • seems fine, [needs sign-off from Niko]
Wait, that's not waiting-on-team?
Also, that conflicts with #85868

Jack Huey said:

Wait, that's not waiting-on-team?

@apiraino ^ ?
T-compiler agenda now has a new section: the 5 most recently updated PRs waiting for review
mmm
Is it supposed to be waiting-on-team?
(I checked the issue to see if it might be a race between agenda construction and label updates, but that does not seem to be the case.)
Oh, this is my fault.
Sorry, sorry, sorry.
Lost track of where I was in the agenda.
Let me back up.

PRs S-waiting-on-team

T-compiler

  • "Extend -Cdebuginfo with new options and named aliases" rust#83947
    • need more user-facing documentation ...
    • ... and we decided to make it a blocker
    • Who should provide documentation? The PR author? Maybe a direct ping?
I think at this point, the PR is no longer waiting on us but waiting on the author to make the appropriate changes.
Oh, I should have looked at the agenda. Sorry for the noise @apiraino
no worries :-) I'll update the label accordingly
Ok, label updated.

Most recent PRs waiting for review

T-compiler

• "move obligation dedup from impl_or_trait_obligations to project caching" rust#84944 (last comment: about 16 days ago)
    • seems fine, needs sign-off from Niko
There we go, sorry for jumping the gun earlier.

Jack Huey said:

Also, that conflicts with #85868

Yeah, it seems like we need to pick one of these PRs to merge.
Note that the changes in #84944 might be able to just be moved to where the function was
IMO we should try to land #85868 since that PR resolves a correctness issue with incremental compilation.
Agreed
If #84944 can be reworked on top of that, it seems reasonable to land as well.
I will leave a comment on #84944.
• "Support #[global_allocator] without the allocator shim" rust#86844 (last comment: about 16 days ago)
I'm a little worried without a test for #85868 though
Agreed but we've landed fixes for other incr-comp issues without regression tests so while I think it would be best to have the test, it doesn't seem blocking to me.
(Just as a time check, I'm going to timebox this part of the agenda to end in 4 minutes so we can hit the rest of the agenda)
I mean, I'm worried to land #84944 without a test from #85868. It's possible it regresses it

Jack Huey said:

I'm a little worried without a test for #85868 though

Maybe we file a followup issue to construct such tests
and then block #84944 on that
I'm not sure I know enough about our allocators story to comment on this PR just from a quick skim.
Is this something wg-allocators is interested in? Or are they inactive?
I will try making a post in their Zulip stream and see if there are any thoughts about this PR from them.
Ok, so that's time for the PRs waiting for review. If there is time at the end, I will come back to the remaining three.

Issues of Note

Short Summary

• 1 T-compiler P-critical issues
    • 1 of those are unassigned

• 83 T-compiler P-high issues
    • 56 of those are unassigned
• 1 P-critical, 3 P-high, 1 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-beta
• 0 P-critical, 1 P-high, 1 P-medium, 2 P-low regression-from-stable-to-nightly
• 1 P-critical, 48 P-high, 81 P-medium, 9 P-low regression-from-stable-to-stable
The unassigned P-critical issue is the stable-to-stable regression we talked about already (addressed by "Split critical edge targeting the start block" rust#88124)
I'll assign to myself to close when the backports land.

P-critical

T-compiler

  • "LLVM crash: Basic Block does not have terminator!" rust#88043
    • reopened to track the stable-to-stable regression
    • (see beta and stable nominations)
Oh, that's what I just mentioned.

T-rustdoc

  • No P-critical issues for T-rustdoc this time.
P-high regressions
P-high beta regressions

• "ICE: unexpected concrete region in borrowck: ReStatic" rust#87455
    • @pnkfelix self-assigned backport of rust#87843, provided PR rust#88190 (approved by @simulacrum)
  • "ICE: unexpected concrete region in borrowck: ReEarlyBound(0, 'a)" rust#83190
    • regression in crate run for 1.55, manifested in a couple of issues
    • should be resolved by rust#88190, authored by Felix

Unassigned P-high nightly regressions

  • No unassigned P-high nightly regressions this time.

Performance logs

triage logs for 2021-08-25

A few regressions but largely an improvement this week, mostly due to the upgrade to LLVM 13.

Triage done by @simulacrum. 2 Regressions, 1 Improvements, 2 Mixed; 0 of them in rollups

Regressions

Update the backtrace crate in libstd #88151

  • Large regression in instruction counts (up to 2.6% on incr-patched: u8 3072 builds of issue-46449)
  • Standard regression from an increase in std/core size due to added items.

Add fast path for Path::cmp that skips over long shared prefixes #86898

  • Small improvement in instruction counts (up to -0.3% on incr-unchanged builds of helloworld)
  • Moderate regression in instruction counts (up to 1.2% on incr-patched: println builds of ripgrep)
  • Largely in -doc builds, seems to be a small but real regression.

Improvements

  • Reenable RemoveZsts #88176

Mixed

Revert "Auto merge of #83417 - erikdesjardins:enableremovezsts, r=oli-obk" #88056

  • Small improvement in instruction counts (up to -0.5% on incr-patched: println builds of cargo)
  • Large regression in instruction counts (up to 4.5% on incr-unchanged builds of deeply-nested-async)

  • Regression is canceled out by the later #88176 (see improvements above).
    Upgrade to LLVM 13 #87570

  • Very large improvement in instruction counts (up to -10.4% on incr-unchanged builds of helloworld)

  • Very large regression in instruction counts (up to 9.6% on full builds of match-stress-enum)
  • Overall an improvement, regressions are significantly more limited to just a
    few cases compared to the improvements seen across the board.

Untriaged Pull Requests

  • #87815 encode generics_of for fields and ty params
  • #87781 Remove box syntax from compiler and tools
  • #87640 Rollup of 9 pull requests
  • #87587 Various refactorings of the TAIT infrastructure
  • #87570 Upgrade to LLVM 13
  • #87244 Better diagnostics with mismatched types due to implicit static lifetime
  • #86777 Include terminators in instance size estimate
  • #86698 Move OnDiskCache to rustc_query_impl.
  • #86588 Rollup of 8 pull requests
  • #86034 Change entry point to shield against exploding payloads
  • #84560 Inline Iterator as IntoIterator.
  • #80357 Introduce hir::ExprKind::Let - Take 2

Nominated Issues

T-compiler

  • "ACCESS_VIOLATION when dereferencing once_cell::Lazy in closure with LTO" rust#81408
    • Windows-only, happens when using LLD linker and building with Thin LTO, a bit more details and a repro from @memoryruins
    • As it seems an LLVM issue, has this been reported upstream? (see comment)
    • Wg-prio assigned P-high, issue is still present with LLVM13 so I-nominated to get more eyeballs on it, where to go from here?

RFC

  • No nominated RFCs for T-compiler this time.
So we do have 5 minutes to talk about the nominated issue.
Hmm titles for #88176 and #83417 sound similar?
(sorry, that was just an idle remark about the performance triage report.)
oh, I see, they were a series of PR's.
yeah just a series of reverts/approvals
#83417 landed first, then #88056 reverted it, and then #88176 re-enabled it

#83417 was merged but that uncovered the P-critical issue we already discussed. #83417 was then reverted before the true issue was fixed (the PR nominated for beta/stable backport). #88176 is the re-enable for the original PR.
do we know what the net effect was? :)
probably too hard to isolate
sorry, I distracted us from the nominated #81408
I think it's just the perf results on the original PR right?
it seems like the main task for #81408 is to file an issue with the LLVM devs?
Hmm #81408 doesn't seem to trigger when link.exe is used which is the default for *-pc-windows-msvc.
I don't know if they're taking rust test cases over there at this point. :) We probably need to convert it into a .ll file example.
Yeah, this seems like an upstream issue.
I imagine the work here is minimizing the LL we get from rustc into something relatively compact that still repro's the issue?
Hans Kratz asked if an upstream issue has been opened: does it need to be done?
(and if yes by whom)
Yeah, it seems like this is an issue with lld. So as Felix mentioned, we'll need to report upstream (probably with a LLVM-IR sample that demonstrates the issue).
I can assign to myself but I probably not have time to work on it in the near future so I don't want that to discourage anyone else from working on it.
Well, that's time.
Thanks @T-compiler/meeting for attending. Have a great morning/afternoon/evening and stay safe! :wave:

Wesley Wiser said:

I can assign to myself but I probably not have time to work on it in the near future so I don't want that to discourage anyone else from working on it.

If it's ok I'll comment explicitating that someone should need to own the upstream bug report to move this issue forward. Is that correct?
and maybe someone will jump in to do it
@apiraino Yes, that's correct.
P-high also seems like the appropriate priority level to me.

Draft for next week's agenda is available at:
https://hackmd.io/3r_D-3ElQ-WR_VVzx4g2Pw?view

Scheduled checkins from:

  • @WG-diagnostics from @Esteban Küber and @oli
  • @WG-rustc-dev-guide from @Santiago Pastorino and @Yuki Okushi
